fields.Title of Presentation: <span style="font-size:11pt;">The impact of a health and wellness course on positive and negative affect in college students</span>
fields.Description/Abstract: <span>INTRO: The 2021 annual report by the Center for Collegiate Mental </span><span>Health</span><span> reported that of 153,233 </span><span>students</span><span> who sought university counseling, 65.5% reported anxiety as a problem, 49.1% reported stress, and 47.2% experienced depression. Over the past twenty years, </span><span>college</span><span> counseling services have also experienced explosive and increasing demand and are struggling to keep up with increasing student needs. In order to help with the demand, </span><span>college</span><span> campuses are seeking numerous ways to help with these challenges. Of interventions studied, </span><span>positive</span><span> psychological approaches, mindfulness, and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) techniques are the most impactful interventions that have demonstrated the greatest efficacy, particularly in improving </span><span>negative</span><span> and </span><span>positive</span><span> </span><span>affect</span><span>. While most </span><span>college</span><span> </span><span>health</span><span> and </span><span>wellness</span><span> courses tend to focus more on physical </span><span>health</span><span> and show improvements on physical efficacy, it would make sense that if the same </span><span>course</span><span>, with additional emphasis on psychological </span><span>health</span><span> and consistently integrating and practicing techniques like CBT, might also improve </span><span>negative</span><span> and </span><span>positive</span><span> </span><span>affect</span><span> scores. </span><b>Purpose:<span> </span></b><span>The purpose of this study is to see if two 15-week </span><span>health</span><span> and </span><span>wellness</span><span> </span><span>college</span><span> courses, taught concurrently from two different perspectives (e.g., traditional approach and CBT approach), will significantly reduce </span><span>negative</span><span> </span><span>affect</span><span> and increase </span><span>positive</span><span> </span><span>affect</span><span> in </span><span>college</span><span>-age </span><span>students</span><span>. </span><b>Hypothesis:<span> </span></b><span>1) Both the control and experimental </span><span>health</span><span> and </span><span>wellness</span><span> courses will facilitate decreased </span><span>negative</span><span> trait </span><span>affect</span><span> and increased </span><span>positive</span><span> trait </span><span>affect</span><span>.</span><span> </span><span>2) If changes in </span><span>affect</span><span> are significant across the 15-week semester, we will test whether improved cognitive distortion scores that occur in the experimental </span><span>course</span><span>, act as a mediator to changes in </span><span>positive</span><span> and </span><span>negative</span><span> </span><span>affect</span><span>. </span><b>Participants:</b><span> Male and female </span><span>college</span><span>-age </span><span>students</span><span> (18-50 years), from different backgrounds and different majors, will be recruited on a volunteer basis after enrolling in one of two 15-week </span><span>health</span><span> and </span><span>wellness</span><span> courses (EXHS 155 at CWI and KINES 141 at BSU). </span><b>Methods:<span> </span></b><span>Students</span><span> will attend two-hours and thirty-minutes of lecture time per week for 15 weeks. Both courses will be taught face-to-face during concurrent semesters (Spring 23) by highly qualified instructors.This study is an experimental design with pre-and post-tests administered to experimental and control groups. </span><span>Students</span><span> will complete the demographic/</span><span>wellness</span><span> questionnaire during the second class of the semester only; they will complete the PANAS-Gen during the second and last classes of the semester, and the CD-Quest will be completed in the second class, and every 3 weeks during the semester (weeks 2, 5, 8, 11, and 14). </span><b>Statistical Analysis:<span> </span></b><span>A mixed model repeated measures ANOVA analysis will be conducted (P </span><<span> .05), with group assignment as the independent variable and changes in PANAS-Gen score as the dependent variable. Previous therapy may be used as a possible covariate. A mixed model repeated measures ANOVA analysis will be conducted to assess changes in cognitive distortions using the CD-Quest results. If statistically significant (p<0.005) changes are found in PANAS-Gen scores from pre-to post-intervention, a mediation linear regression analysis will be run to examine whether changes in PANAS-Gen scores were mediated by changes in cognitive behavioral strategies (CD-Quest). Statistical analysis will be conducted using SPSS V28.0.1. </span><b>Expected Outcomes:<span> </span></b><span>Both </span><span>health</span><span> and </span><span>wellness</span><span> courses will result in improved </span><span>negative</span><span> and </span><span>positive</span><span> </span><span>affect</span><span> scores. For the experimental </span><span>course</span><span>, reduced cognitive distortions will mediate reductions in </span><span>negative</span><span> </span><span>affect</span><span>.</span>
